messages.message:
I think the problem was that celery==4.2.1 updated their kombu dependency which internally requires the redis 3.2.0.

We should pin the kombu dep as well in our requirements.txt to make sure that this doesn’t happen again.
ah ok, it's a recent problem?

yeah — I think it is a very recent change.  I recently upgraded my local celery version and ran into similar problems.  Looking into their history, it seems that the problem exists with recent changes to celery 4.2.1

Interesting. I believe the issue has to do with redis-server locally running a newer version than the redis we run in docker, which requires a newer Python client version. @Karthik S fixed this. You can either upgrade your redis-py or you can downgrade your redis-server to the Docker version and that should work
